text: IN THE COURT OF APPEAL OF THE DEMOCRATIC SOCIALIST
In the matter of an application for Mandates
in the nature of Writs of Certiorari and
Prohibition under and in terms of Article 140
of the Constitution of the Democratic Socialist
182. Widiye Gedara Koshika Madushan Bandara Widiye
220. Urala Gamage Ayadya Chandra Keerthi Gamage,
Yaya, Ihala Gomugamuwa. 268. Danansuriya Arachchilage Sisira Kumara E69/1,
272. Marakkala Manage Hasanthi Dushani De Silva,
Prime Minister and Minister of Finance,
Sasana, Cultural, Water Supply and Urban
Ministry, 58, Sir Ernest De Silva Mawatha,
Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and
Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and
Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and
Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and
BEFORE : K. M. G. H. KULATUNGA, J.
COUNSEL : Saliya Pieris, P.C., with Thanuka Nandasiri, Dinithi Jayasinghe,
and Dhimarsha Marso for the Petitioners, instructed by Danuka
Rajika Aluwihare, S.C., for the Respondents.
K. M. G. H. KULATUNGA, J.
1. 394 petitioners in this application, inter alia, are seeking writs of
a. by prayer (c), grant and issue a mandate in the nature of a writ of
prohibition prohibiting the respondents and/or any other person
working under the respondents from recruiting and/or
appointing any other person and/or persons other than the
petitioners to the post of Archaeological Assistant and Watcher in
b. by prayer (d), grant and issue a mandate in the nature of a writ
of mandamus directing all and/or several and/or one of the
respondents to reinstate the petitioners in service in the posts
they held in the Central Cultural Fund or Archaeological
Department as per documents annexed to P-1 to P-394 and to
make the said appointments of the petitioners permanent in
terms of the Public Administration Circulars 25/2014 and
2. This matter was taken up for argument on 29.07.2025. Upon so
concluding, post-argument written submissions were tendered on
09.10.2025 and 20.11.2025, respectively. Then, a motion dated
29.08.2025 was also filed on behalf of the 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 7th
respondents, along with which the marksheets of the interviews held in
2019 were tendered as X-1 and X-2.
3. These petitioners were initially recruited for the posts of Archaeological
Assistants (labourers) on the approval of the Board of the Central
Cultural Fund (“the CCF”). The said recruitment, according to the
Letters of Appointment, was contractual in nature initially for a period
of one year. The several petitioners were so appointed on three different
i. 1st to 337th petitioners, with effect from 23.11.2017;
ii. 338th to 387th petitioners, with effect from 01.05.2018; and
iii. 338th to 394th petitioners, with effect from 14.02.2019.
It is the position of the petitioners that the periods of contract were
subsequently extended. The said extensions lapsed as follows:
Accordingly, the 1st to the 337th petitioners have been serving on such
contractual basis for approx. 2 years and 3 months, the 338th to the
387th petitioners for 2 years, and the 338th to the 394th petitioners for 1
year. The petitioners claim that according to clause 12 of the initial
Letters of Appointment, there was an intimation to the effect that the
petitioners will be absorbed into the Department of Archaeology subject
to relevant approvals. The said clause reads as follows:
“පුරාවිද්‍යා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුව මඟින්ත කළමනාකරණ ද ේවා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුවට ඉදිරිපත් කර ඇති දමම තනුරු අනුමත වීදමන්ත අනුරුව යථා කාලදේ දී ඔබ පුරාවිද්‍යා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුවට අනුයුක්ත කිරීමට නියමිතය.”
4. According to the respondents, these recruitments on contractual basis
were necessitated in order to safeguard the archaeological sites across
the island, and in view of the urgency, they were so recruited on
contractual basis. Recruitments on this basis had been made as there
had not been cadre approval to accommodate the required number of
employees at that point. To meet this exigency and due to the urgency,
the 1st respondent, the CCF, has agreed to recruit the petitioners on
such contract basis and assign them to the Department of Archaeology
(vide R-1 and R-2). It is thus admitted and conceded by the respondents
that the petitioners were employed on such contractual basis. However
the respondents claim that it was strictly on such basis for a specific
time period. The respondents also concede that such contracts initially
granted were in fact extended in respect of two categories of petitioners
5. The position of the respondents is that, at all material times, the
petitioners were employees of the CCF. Thereafter, with the approval of
the Director General of the Department of Management Services, cadre
positions for 865 Archaeological Assistants and 1,000 watchers were
approved within the Department of Archaeology (vide 4R-4). Then, by
public notice dated 03.04.2019, applications were called for to fill these
vacancies. The petitioners submit that, by letter P-2, dated 21.11.2018,
an intimation was made that the said vacancies and positions would be
filled by the Department of Archaeology, following the due interview
procedure. It is thus common ground that applications were called for
by P-3(1) on 03.04.2019, which was on an open competitive basis. The
petitioners admit having applied in response to the said notice for the
6. All the 6400 applicants have accordingly been interviewed in 2020. The
petitioners allege that for five years, the said marks were not made
available, including to the petitioners, and that there was no
communication. It is their position that the purported marks were
tendered to this Court by way of a motion dated 03.09.2025. The said
list, containing the details of the applicants who obtained the cut-off
mark for the respective two posts, was so made available as X-1 and X-
2, by motion dated 29.08.2025. The petitioners allege that the said
priority lists do not contain and/or comprise the entire mark sheet in
detail and thus claim to be prejudicial to the petitioners. These lists
contain only those who obtained the cut-off mark.
7. That being so, the primary argument of the petitioners is that the
petitioners have a legitimate expectation arising from clause 12 of their
initial Letters of Appointment, and the failure to make available the
mark sheets since 2020 has caused further prejudice, and this has
resulted in the continuity and prolonging of the legitimate expectation
8. As opposed to this, the position of the respondents, basically, is that
the petitioners’ initial letters were issued by the CCF, which was purely
of a contractual nature with the CCF and does not create a legitimate
expectation in the petitioners to be absorbed into the permanent cadre
9. The respondents also rely on the Management Services Circular No. 2
of 2020 (5R-2), which, by para 2 (viii), stipulates that the recruitment to
the Primary Grade should be carried out exclusively by the newly
established Multi-Purpose Development Task Force. Then, para 2 (ix)
has reiterated the suspension of recruitment of the said grade by
10. Then, in the course of the arguments on 29.07.2025, the learned State
Counsel did submit that the Department of Archaeology has recruited
263 Watchers and 816 Archaeological Assistants, both under Grade
PL(1) from the Multi-Purpose Development Task Force during the period
01.09.2023 to 28.05.2024. It was also submitted that as at 30.06.2025,
a total of 1,114 vacancies in the PL(1) Grade, comprising of 293
Archaeological Assistants and 821 Watchers were available at the
Department of Archaeology. It is the position of the petitioners that the
said recruitments have been made in total disregard of and undermining
the legitimate expectation of the petitioners. It is also averred in the
written submissions of the petitioners that a considerable number of
such vacancies have already been filled through external recruitment,
without affording the petitioners priority or a fair opportunity for
consideration. Accordingly, the learned President’s Counsel for the
petitioners submits that, still for all, there is a sufficient number of
vacancies to accommodate all the petitioners, even at this juncture.
11. It is common ground that the petitioners have applied for the respective
posts and faced an interview in or around 2020. The priority list based
on the cut-off mark of 45 had been made available, marked X-1. However,
due to an intervening Circular 01/2020, all recruitments had been
suspended. In this backdrop, though interviews were so held and a
priority list compiled, no recruitments were in fact made based on the
12. Accordingly, the position of the respondents is:
a. that the petitioners are not entitled to any relief arising from the
abandoned recruitment process, as its abandonment has not
been challenged and no relief has been sought in that regard;
b. that the petitioners cannot have a legitimate expectation to be
appointed to the posts merely by participating in the recruitment
c. that paragraph 12 of the letters of appointment does not/cannot
give rise to a legitimate expectation of permanent employment
d. that the petitioners do have a legal right enforceable in public law
to be reinstated to service in terms of the letters of appointment
e. that the Public Administration Circulars marked P-4(i) and P-4(ii)
are not applicable to the petitioners’ circumstances.
13. In view of Circular No. 01/2020 (5R-1), the interview process and
recruitments were all stalled and suspended. There onwards,
recruitments for the Primary Grades (PL(1), PL(2) and PL(3)) in all
government public institutions were suspended. Then, by virtue of
Circular No. 02/2020 (5R-2), such recruitments to the Primary Grade
was carried out exclusively through the newly established Multi-Purpose
Development Task Force. In these circumstances, the petitioners who
were successful in the 2020 interviews were not issued with the
interview results or marks. The entire process was suspended. In the
interim, the periods of contract of the petitioners were all determined
14. As submitted by the learned State Counsel, it appears that, long
thereafter, direct recruitments have been made from the Multi-Purpose
Development Task Force and certain of the vacancies have now been
filled. The issue for determination is whether the petitioners have a
legitimate expectation to be appointed or recruited to the said vacancies
on a permanent basis. At this juncture, it is necessary to refer to the
relief sought by prayer (d). The learned State Counsel argues that the
relief sought is for reinstatement, and it cannot be granted. The
argument is that a reinstatement sought is based on the abandoned
process of recruitment, and the petitioners have not challenged the said
abandonment. However, on a careful and close perusal of prayer (d) it is
apparent that the petitioners have sought to be reinstated in service in
the posts they held under P-1 to P-394 (as per the original letters of
appointment and contract). However, the said relief also seeks writs of
mandamus directing the respondents to make the said appointments of
the said petitioners permanent in terms of the Public Administration
Circulars marked P-4(i) and P-4(ii). These two Circulars provide for the
appointment and/or making permanent those who hold certain posts on
a contractual basis. The relevant portion, from P-4(ii), are as follows:

“තාවකාලික, අනියේ (දද්‍නික), ආදේශක, දකාන්තරාත් ද ෝ න පද්‍නම මත බඳවාදෙන ඇති ද ේවකයින්ත ඳ ා ේීර පත්වීේ ප්‍රද්‍ානය කිරීම 01. 2016.04.04 දිනැති රාජ්‍ය පරිපාලන චක්‍රදේඛ 25/2014(ii) මඟින්ත අවලංගු කරන ලද්‍ ඉ ත කරුණ ා ේබන්තධව නිකුත් කර ඇති 2014.11.12 දිනැති රාජ්‍ය පරිපාලන චක්‍රදේඛ 25/2014 ා 2014.12.29 දිනැති රාජ්‍ය පරිපාලන චක්‍රදේඛ 25/2014(i) දකදරහි අවධානය දයාමු කරවමි. 02. ඉ ත 25/2014 ා 25/2014(i) ද්‍රන රාජ්‍ය පරිපාලන චක්‍රදේඛයන්තහි ඳ න්ත සුදුසුකේ ේූර්ණ කළ යුු දිනය 2019.09.01 දල ළකා එදිනට සුදුසුකේ ේූර්ණ කර ඇති නිලධරයන්ත එදින සිට දමහි ප ත ඳ න්ත i ා ii දකාන්තදේසි වලට යටත්ව ේිර කිරීමට ැකිවන පරිදි රාජ්‍ය පරිපාලන චක්‍රදේඛ 25/2014 ා 25/2014(i) යළි බලාත්මක කිරීමට 2019.09.17 දින පැවති අමාතය මණ්ඩල රැ ේවීදේ දී තීරණය කර ඇත.

i. ඉ ත පරිදි ේිර පත්වීේ ලබා දීදමන්ත අනුරුව විශ්‍රාම වැටුප් වයව ේථා ංග්‍ර ය යටදත් විශ්‍රාම වැටුපක් ඳ ා ේූර්ණ කළ යුු අවශයතා ේූර්ණ කළ ැකි නිලධරයන්ත ඳ ා ේිර විශ්‍රාම වැටුප් හිත පත්වීේ ලබා දීම. ii. ඉ ත i හි ඳ න්ත අවශයතා ේූර්ණ කළ දනා ැකි නිලධරයන්ත ඳ ා රාජ්‍ය ද ේවක අර්ථ ාධක අරමුද්‍ල යටදත් ේිර පත්වීේ ලබාදීම. 03. ඉ ත පරිදි ක්‍රියාකිරීමට අද්‍ාළ පත්කිරීදේ බලධරයන්ත ක්‍රියා කළ යුු ය. 04. දමම චක්‍රදේඛය ම ා භාණ්ඩාොරදේ එකඟතාව ඇතිව නිකුත් කරන ලදී.”
To that extent, the argument of the learned State Counsel is
misconceived and is not convincing. The petitioners are, in fact, seeking
that they be appointed to the vacancies in respect of the relevant posts
referred to in P-1 to P-394.
15. To this end, the petitioners are basing their right and entitlement
primarily on legitimate expectation. Prof. Craig, in ‘Administrative Law’
(7th Ed., at p.677), defines procedural and substantive legitimate

“The phrase ‘procedural legitimate expectation’ denotes the existence of some process right the applicant claims to possess as the result of a promise or behaviour by the public body that generates the expectation….. The phrase ‘substantive legitimate expectation’ captures the situation in which the applicant seeks a particular benefit or commodity, such as a welfare benefit or a license, as the result of some promise, behaviour or representation made by the public body.” The ideology of ‘substantive’ legitimate expectation originated in the
landmark case of R vs. Ministry of Agriculture Fisheries and Food,
ex parte Hamble (Offshore) Fisheries Ltd (1995) 2 All ER 714, where

“Legitimacy in this sense is not an absolute. It is a function of expectations induced by government and of policy considerations which militate against their fulfilment. The balance must in the first instance be for the policy maker to strike; but if the outcome is challenged by way of judicial review, I do not consider that the Court's criterion is the bare rationality of the policy maker's conclusion. While policy is for the policy-maker alone, the fairness of his or her decision not to accommodate reasonable expectations which the policy will thwart remains the Court's concern (as of course the lawfulness of the policy). To postulate this is not to place the judge in the seat of the Minister...but it is equally the court’s duty to protect the interests of those individuals whose expectation of different treatment has a legitimacy which in fairness outtops the policy choice which threatens to frustrate it.” [emphasis added].
16. The abovementioned dictum of Sedley, J. has been cited with approval
in the Sri Lankan decisions of Dayaratne vs. Minister of Health and
Indigenous Medicine (1999) 1 SLR 393, in Nimalsiri vs. Fernando
(SC/FR/256/2010, decided on 17.09.2015), and in M. R. C. C.
Ariyarathne and others vs. Inspector General of Police and others
(SC/FR/444/2012, decided on 30.07.2019). In M. R. C. C. Ariyarathne
and others vs. Inspector General of Police and others (supra),
Prasanna Jayawardena, P.C., J., after an extensive and all-
encompassing analysis on the doctrine of legitimate expectation, cited
with approval the following dicta of Dehideniya, J.’s decision in Zamrath
vs. Sri Lanka Medical Council (SC/FR/119/2019, decided on
23.07.2019), as the rationale underlying the doctrine of legitimate

“The legitimate expectation of a person … further ensures legal certainty which is imperative as the people ought to plan their lives, secure in the knowledge of the consequences of their actions. The perception of legal certainty deserves protection, as a basic tenet of the rule of law which this court attempts to uphold as the apex court of the country. The public perception of legal certainty becomes negative when the authorities by their own undertakings and assurances have generated legitimate expectations of people and subsequently by their own conduct, infringe the so generated expectations.”
17. In R. vs. North and East Devon Health Authority, ex p Coughlan
[2001] QB 213, Lord Woolf, M.R. (giving the judgment of the Court
consisting of himself, Mummery and Sedley L.JJ.), as follows:

“Where the court considers that a lawful promise or practice has induced a legitimate expectation of a benefit which is substantive, not simply procedural, authority now establishes that here too the court will in a proper case decide whether to frustrate the expectation is so unfair that to take a new and different course will amount to an abuse of power.” [emphasis added.]
The above dicta confirms that an erroneous decision cannot create a
legitimate expectation. Further, in Siriwardane vs. Seneviratne and
four others [2011] 2 SLR 1, Dr. Shirani Bandaranayake, J. (as her
Ladyship then was), held as follows:

“A careful consideration of the doctrine of legitimate expectation, clearly shows that, whether an expectation is legitimate or not is a question of fact. This has to be decided not only on the basis of the application made by the aggrieved party before court, but also taking into consideration whether there had been any arbitrary exercise of power by the administrative authority in question.” [emphasis added.]
18. Being mindful of the aforesaid, I will now consider if clause 12 of the
letters P-1 to P-394 creates a legitimate expectation. This clause
certainly does hold out that upon the approval of the said posts by the
Department of Management Services, the petitioners are due to be
attached to the Department of Archaeology in due course. This is a clear
holding out that at some point in time, upon the cadre approval, the
petitioners will be attached to the Department of Archaeology. The
determinate factor specifically referred to therein is the approval of the
said posts by the Department of Management Services. The learned
State Counsel argues that this is a mere information and not a promise
19. The plain reading of the said clause simply means what it says, and
that’s no more and no less than that the attachments will be made to
the Department of Archaeology upon the realisation or receiving of cadre
approval. These petitioners have been appointed on contract basis to two
specific posts. The cadre approval was to be obtained in the future. When
the petitioners are informed that attachment would be made with the
approval, that means that they will be so appointed. This certainly
creates an expectation, and as it is based on a lawful basis, to my mind,
20. I will now consider if the sequence of events that is common ground
between the parties in fact is sufficient to create such a legitimate
expectation. The starting point is the initial letters of appointment, P-1
to P-394. The petitioners have been serving between 1 – 3 years in such
posts and positions. The learned State Counsel does inferentially argue
that the said letters of appointment were not given by the Department
of Archaeology, but the CCF. The argument is that in the absence of any
direct holding out, promise, or representation by the Department of
Archaeology, the petitioners cannot have a legitimate expectation which
would bind the Department of Archaeology. To this end, I observe that
4R-1 is relevant. This is a letter written by the Director General of the
Department of Archaeology, dated 04.09.2017, to the Director General
of the CCF. Paragraphs 1 and 4 read as follows:

“01. ෙරු අධයාපන අමාතයුමාදේ ප්‍රධානත්වදයන්ත අමාතයාංශ දේකේුමාදේ භාගීත්වදයන්ත පැවති ප්‍රෙති මාදලෝචන රැ ේවීදේදී ශීර්ෂෙත කරුණ ේබන්තධදයන්ත තීරණය කළ පරිදි පුරාවිද්‍යා ේථාන ඳ ා ඔබ ආයතනය මඟින්ත ද ේවකයින්ත බඳවා ෙැනීදමන්ත පසු පුරාවිද්‍යා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුව දවත අනුයුක්ත කිරීමට තීරණය කරන ලදි. … 04. ඔවුන්ත පසු කාලයක දී පුරාවිද්‍යා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුවට අන්තතර්ග්‍ර ණය කර ෙැනීදේ ැකියාව පිළිබඳව කාර්යය මණ්ඩල දතාරුරු කළමණාකරන ද ේවා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුව දවත ඉදිරිපත් කරනු ලබන ද යින්ත දමයට අමුණා ඇති බඳවා ෙැනීදේ පටිපාටිදේ සුදුසුකේ ලත් අය පමණක් බඳවා ෙැනීමට කටයුු කිරීම සුදුසු දේ.”
21. According to which, the Director General of Archaeology has informed
that upon a discussion held with the Minister and the Secretary, it has
been decided that the persons who may be recruited to the CCF, upon
being so recruited, would be attached to the Department of Archaeology.
Further it has also been stated by the Director General, in no uncertain
terms, that the said recruitments to the CCF be made in accordance
with the scheme of recruitment of persons with the requisite
qualifications, as such persons are due to be absorbed to the
Department of Archaeology. This, as I see, is a clear holding out by the
Director General of Archaeology that, in fact, the petitioner, in due
22. The use of the words ‘attach’ (‘අනුයුක්ත’) and ‘absorb’ (‘අන්තතර්ග්‍ර ණය’) in
this letter is very significant and relevant. ‘Attach’ is defined in the
Black’s Law Dictionary (8th Ed.) as follows:
“attach vb. 1. To annex, bind or fasten.”
As for attachment in the context of employment, it will mean that upon
the recruitment to the CCF, such persons will, at some point, be annexed
to or taken over by the Department of Archaeology. Then, the word
‘absorption’, used in paragraph 4, clearly establishes that the future
attachment to the Department of Archaeology goes beyond a mere
‘appointment’. An appointment will contemplate a form of employment
in the first instance. However, ‘absorption’ will presuppose some form of
appointment with one agency (the CCF) that would be regularised within
the Department of Archaeology, which would contemplate a form of
merger between the employment in the CCF and the Department of
Archaeology. According to the Black’s Law Dictionary (8th Ed.),
“absorption n. 1. The act or process of including or incorporating
a thing into something else. … 3. Labor Law. In a postmerger
collective-bargaining agreement a provision allowing seniority for
union members in the resulting entity.”
Such attachment and absorption may then entail or require the issuance
of a formal letter at that point, which will intimate the said attachment
23. Next, the Board Paper 4R-2A, bearing No. 204.12.1, becomes relevant.
The subject of this Board paper is the recruitment of watchers and
labourers for the archaeological sites and the protection of
archaeological artefacts. This Board Paper confirms that which is stated
in paragraphs 1 and 4 of 4R-1. The said Board Paper specifically
provides that these recruitments are specifically until the approval of the
cadre of the Department of Archaeology. Similarly, the Director General
of Archaeology has, by 4R-4, once again intimated that the proposed
cadre increase had been approved, and as there may be a delay in
recruitment, the period of contract of the labourers and watchers, who
were recruited by the CCF, be extended. In this backdrop, in 2019,
interviews have been called for to fill in the vacancies for the posts of
Archaeological Assistants and Watchers in the Department of
Archaeology. It appears that the petitioners have submitted themselves
to the said interviews. The mark sheet of the candidates who secured
the required cut-off mark was tendered to this Court marked X-1 and X-
2. According to which, 98 petitioners have been successful in obtaining
the cut-off mark. The said petitioners are the 1st, 18th, 21st, 43rd, 49th,
24. It is upon the said interviews by a circular dated 21.02.2020, bearing
No. 1/2020, the Ministry of Finance and Policy Development has made
a general directive in respect of recruitments to the State, as well as to
State Institutions, by which all recruitments will continue to be
suspended. Paragraph 2 of the said Circular specifically provides that
all recruitments to categories PL-1, PL-2, and PL-3 would continue to be

“ඒ අනුව සියලුම අමාතයාංශ, දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තු ඒ යටදත් වන සියලුම ආයතනයන්තහි ප්‍රාථමික ද ේවා ෙණදේ (PL-1, PL-2 PL-3) ද්‍ැනට පවතින සියලුම පුරප්පාඩු ඳ ා බඳවාෙැනීේ නැවත ද්‍ැනුේ දද්‍න ුරු අත්හිටුවීමට 2020.01.22 දින පැවති අමාතය මණ්ඩල රැ ේවීදේදී තීරණය කර ඇති අතර එකී තීරණය පරිදි කටයුු කිරීමට පියවර ෙත යුුය.” 25. Then, by Circular No. 2/2020, dated 26.10.2020, issued by the Ministry
of Finance and Policy Development, provided for the recruitment to the
approved cadre of persons and filling of vacancies thereto. According to
paragraph 2(viii) thereof, it provides as follows:

“ප්‍රාථමික ද ේවා ෙණදේ (PL) තනුරු ඳ ා අවශය ද ේවක පිරි ේ බහුකාර්ය ංවර්ධන කාර්ය ාධක බලකා දද්‍පාර්තදේන්තුව මඟින්ත ලබාදීමට තීරණය කර ඇත.” This requires that all recruitments to the PL category be made through
the Multi-Purpose Development Task Force. These circulars have also
been tendered by the respondents by motion dated 12.06.2023, marked
once again as X-1 and X-2. The position of the respondents is that in
view of the said circulars, the recruitment of the petitioners, including
those who were successful at the interviews held in 2019, could not be
processed and made. Accordingly, the learned State Counsel argues that
the petitioners are thus not entitled to seek employment as prayed for.
26. I will now consider this argument in the light of the events that
transpired between 2019 and 2021. At the very outset, the petitioners
have certainly been recruited on contract basis by the CCF for the
specific purpose and object of them being employed for the purposes of
the Department of Archaeology. The use of the words ‘attachment’ and
‘absorption’ clearly puts it beyond doubt that the petitioners, though
recruited on contract basis by the CCF, were in fact so recruited on
behalf of the Department of Archaeology, at least to the extent that the
persons so recruited whilst being physically employed at various
archaeological sites were intended to be so absorbed and attached to the
Department of Archaeology upon the cadre approval. In these
circumstances, the petitioners certainly will have the expectation of
being attached and absorbed to the Department of Archaeology without
any other interview or examination. However, by 4R-4 and 4R-5, there
appears to have been a change that such persons may be required to
face an interview. It is in view of this change of policy and procedure that
the petitioners have applied and faced the interviews in 2019.
27. Up until such time, all the petitioners did have a legitimate expectation
of being absorbed to the Department of Archaeology. However, the
petitioners, by voluntarily submitting themselves to the 2019 interviews,
have, by their act and deed of so submitting, agreed to abide by the
outcome of such an interview. Therefore, the petitioners, unless they
were successful in obtaining the cut-off mark, would forfeit and lose
their legitimate expectation to be recruited on the strength of the original
letters. However, as for the 98 petitioners who were successful, their
right to be recruited on the said interview and the said legitimate
expectation would continue, and they are entitled to demand that they
28. It is thereafter that circulars No. 1/2020 and 2/2020, X-1 and X-2,
submitted with motion dated 12.06.2023, come into operation.
Strangely, there is a drastic change of policy as to the source of drawing
persons for appointments to the category PL-1. The eligibility for
recruitment is limited to those who were in the Multi-Purpose
Development Task Force. By this process, the respondents have
effectively disentitled and prevented the petitioners from being eligible to
the said vacancies in the PL-1 to PL-3 posts. There is no reason or
rationale forthcoming for this change of policy except that the persons
in the said Task Force are, as claimed by the learned State Counsel,
persons with some training and orientation.
29. As stated hereinabove, the petitioners in fact possessed the required
qualifications, and at least a year’s experience in the respective positions
cannot per se be found or deemed not to have the minimum requisite
aptitude or competence to be recruited to such positions. On the face of
it, a sudden change of policy has certainly denied and violated the
legitimate expectation of the petitioners, particularly those 98
petitioners who were successful at the interviews. The said circular No.
02/2020, along with the decision to follow the same, appears to be mala
fide. In the absence of any express rationale or reason, it appears to be
so implemented either to deliberately prevent the petitioners from being
eligible or for some other extraneous reason. Even if it may not be
express malice in acting so, there is, in the least, malice in law, which,
according to ‘Principles of Administrative Law’ by Jain and Jain (8th Ed.,

“Mala fide exercise of power does not necessarily imply any moral turpitude as a matter of law. It only means that the statutory power is exercised for purposes foreign to those for which the law intended.” [emphasis added]. Then also, Wade & Forsyth in ‘Administrative Law’ (11th Ed., at page
354) where the author states as follows,

It is extremely rare for public authorities to be found guilty of intentional dishonesty: normally they are found to have erred, if at all, by ignorance or misunderstanding. Yet the courts constantly accuse them of bad faith merely because they have acted unreasonably or on improper grounds. Again and again it is laid down that powers must be exercised reasonably and in good faith. But in this context ‘in good faith’ means merely ‘for legitimate reasons’. Contrary to the natural sense of the words, they impute no moral obliquity.” [emphasis added].

“And Lord Greene MR…treated bad faith as interchangeable with unreasonableness and extraneous considerations. Bad faith therefore scarcely has an independent existence as a distinct ground of invalidity.” [emphasis added]. 30. Accordingly, on the one hand, the 98 petitioners who had a legitimate
expectation of being recruited has been denied and their expectations
violated. Similarly, the decision to change the policy by Circular No.
02/2020 cannot be said to have been done in good faith, and in any
event, is unreasonable vis-à-vis the said 98 petitioners, as it appears
that the same was for an extraneous consideration and made in bad
faith, to that extent. Even if this does not necessarily imply any moral
turpitude, such exercise of power is mala fide as a matter of law.
31. Accordingly, I hold that the 98 petitioners hereinafter mentioned are
entitled to the relief as follows, in respect of prayer (d). A writ of
mandamus is accordingly issued directing the respondent 5A, the
Director General of the Department of Archaeology, to appoint the 1st,
366th, 384th, 386th, and 390th petitioners to the respective posts such
petitioner has been successful at the interviews as depicted in X-1 and
X-2. The said appointments are to be made with effect from a date
preceding the date on which appointments were made to these posts,
upon the cadre approval. However, the said petitioners will not be
entitled to any payments of wages or other emoluments for the said
period until the actual assumption of duties. However, the said period
of service be considered in determining the salary, emoluments, and
other entitlements as at the date of actual assumption of duties upon
appointments being made as per this Judgement. The prayer seeks a
mandamus to make the petitioners permanent in terms of the Public
Administration Circulars No. 25/2014 and 29/2019. However, as relief
is granted on the basis of the interviews held in 2019, vide X-1 and X-2,
the writ is issued in the aforesaid form, which this Court is empowered
and authorised to do, considering the relief that was prayed for.
However, as the relief by way of mandamus is so granted, the
consideration of relief prayed for by prayer (c) does not arise.
Accordingly, the same is not granted.
32. Relief as aforesaid is hereby granted to the 98 petitioners, namely the
applications of the other petitioners, they are hereby refused and
rejected, as they have failed to establish a legal basis which entitles them
33. The applications of the said 98 petitioners are allowed, and relief is
granted to that extent, and of the others are dismissed. However, I make
JUDGE OF THE COURT OF APPEAL
